content: Check your addressbook. You may have a caldav link to google addresses using your univ account.
creator: davidsk

content: Personally, I do not recommend using Gmail's AllMail folder, as it is a duplicate to other folders; is managed by Gmail, not thunderbird; increases disk space and slows processing; and often causes confusion to user. But that's just my opinion. But, I am not aware of any size restriction. I would exit TB, copy the mbox to the Mail\Local Folders folder and then restart TB.
creator: davidsk

content: You probably need an app password. Many email providers (e.g., gmail and others) now require them when accessing account from personal computers. This URL may help: https://support.apple.com/en-us/102654
creator: davidsk

content: Stai quindi usando una versione personalizzata da Canonical? In formato DEB o Snap?

content: One option is to drag the right side of screen to make it wider, or press F11 for full screen. Another option is to click view>wide view.

content: Click the icon to the right of the 'quick filter' button that is above the message list. Click 'table view' .

content: Also, press F8 key to show or hide email content

content: Is this person receiving error messages? You might check to see if your email provider is restricting access due to attachments . Thunderbird would not deny receipt of an email.

content: Click to account settings. Then scroll down left side to 'Outgoing servers (SMTP) and highlight your SMTP server and press the edit button. There, you can set STARTTLS.
creator: davidsk

content: Hi, If it matters only about the Calendars, why don't you use the CalDav mechanism supported natively in TB, instead of using a add-on?
creator: shopov.bogomil

content: That sounds like the folder is threaded. Highlight the folder, if menu bar is present, click view, sort by and tick 'unthreaded' . If menu bar is not visible, first press alt key and then click view and then sort by
creator: davidsk

content: Access Thunderbird's password vault and delete the stored passwords. See Password Manager - Remember, delete and change passwords in Thunderbird
creator: stancestans

content: Restoring from a backup is the best option. Why it happens every few months is beyond me. Anything could cause corruption of data. We could be looking at third-party software, especially antivirus programs. They are well known for causing havoc with Thunderbird. If you haven't already, I strongly recommend you add Thunderbird's data to your antivirus' exclusions list (whitelist).
creator: stancestans
